title: China appoints new trade representative as US tariff war heats up - (Published 12 hour(s), 14 minute(s) ago)
content: Li Chenggang will replace Wang Shouwen as China's top international trade negotiator at the Ministry of Commerce ...
resumen: China appointed Li Chenggang as the new international trade representative at the Ministry of Commerce (Mofcom) on Wednesday amid a trade war with the United States. Li will replace 59-year-old Wang Shouwen. Li, 58, has decades of experience handling international negotiations at Mofcom and served as China’s ambassador to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) from 2021. He holds a bachelor’s degree in law from Peking University and a master’s degree in the economics of law from the University of Hamburg in Germany. Alfredo Montufar-Helu, a senior adviser to the China Center at US-based research group The Conference Board, said Li might be seen as someone who could break the impasse in the negotiations. US President Donald Trump has raised tariffs on Chinese goods by 145 per cent since returning to office in January. Last Friday, Chinese commerce minister Wang Wentao spoke with WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala about the US’ tariff policies. Wang Yiwei, director of the Institute of International Affairs at Renmin University in Beijing and a former Chinese diplomat, said Li’s knowledge of the WTO would be important in his new role. During his time at the WTO, Li was vocal in conveying Beijing’s opposition to Trump’s tariff policies. Currently, Vice-Premier He Lifeng is the lead official handling China-US economic affairs. China began appointing international trade negotiation representatives holding a ministerial-level rank in 2010.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Draft Executive Order Calls for Restructuring of State Department - (Published 17 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: Supreme Court: Trump administration lawyers urged the Supreme Court in a court filing on Saturday to reject an emergency request to temporarily block deportations of Venezuelans under a rarely invoked ...
resumen: Senator Chris Van Hollen of Maryland accused the Trump administration of “outright defying” court orders to return Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, a wrongly deported Maryland man. Van Hollen met with Abrego Garcia in El Salvador last week and urged the administration to stop releasing unfavorable records about him. Van Hollen said the administration is “flouting the courts as we speak” and “facilitating his return means something more than doing nothing, and they are doing nothing.” A federal appeals court ordered the Trump administration to take a more active role in bringing back Abrego Garcia, after the Supreme Court ruled that the government should “facilitate” his return from El Salvador. The White House has publicized an allegation of domestic abuse from Abrego Garcia’s wife from 2021 and cited a police filing from a Tennessee trooper who stopped Abrego Garcia in 2022. Van Hollen said that Donald Trump is trying to change the subject and should “put up or shut up in court instead of litigating this through social media.” Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, brought Patty Morin, the mother of Rachel Morin, to a press briefing. A federal judge described the government’s claims accusing Abrego Garcia of being a member of the transnational street gang, MS-13, as “unsubstantiated.” Van Hollen expressed his sympathies toward Ms. Morin’s family while emphasizing the importance of ensuring due process for all of those in the United States. Van Hollen warned that the outcome of Abrego Garcia’s case could ultimately threaten the constitutional rights of U.S. citizens. Van Hollen also responded to some Democrats who were critical of his trip and the attention Mr. Abrego Garcia’s case has generated, including Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, who called the issue “a distraction.” Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, conceded that Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia “was not supposed to be sent” to El Salvador. Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. dissented in the Supreme Court’s decision to block the Trump administration from deporting a group of Venezuelan migrants, calling the court’s order “hastily and prematurely granted.” Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, said the Supreme Court should hold Trump administration officials in contempt if they continue to ignore a court order to facilitate Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia’s return from El Salvador. Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the Democratic leader, said that the energy of the Democratic Party right now is across the board and that this is a moment of right versus wrong. Senator Chris van Hollen said that President Trump “is trying to change the subject” by claiming Abrego Garcia is a member of the MS-13 gang and that Trump is “outright defying” the Supreme Court order to facilitate Abrego Garcia’s return. At the heart of two major legal cases challenging the Trump administration’s deportation actions are due process and habeas corpus. The Trump administration deported Venezuelan immigrants accused of being gang members, denying them a court hearing before they were expelled. The Supreme Court temporarily blocked their removal. The Trump administration deported a Maryland man to El Salvador in what the administration initially acknowledged was a mistake. A federal judge ordered the government to facilitate the return of the man, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, but it has not done so. Due process is the idea that people should have access to fair treatment before the law. Habeas corpus means that people who are in government custody have a right to challenge their status in a court hearing. A draft of a Trump administration executive order proposes a drastic restructuring of the State Department that includes eliminating almost all of its Africa operations and shutting down embassies and consulates across the continent. The draft also calls for cutting offices at State Department headquarters that address climate change and refugee issues, as well as democracy and human rights concerns. The purpose of the executive order is to impose “a disciplined reorganization” of the State Department and “streamline mission delivery” while cutting “waste, fraud and abuse.” The draft executive order calls for ending the foreign service exam for aspiring diplomats, and it lays out new hiring criteria that includes “alignment with the president’s foreign policy vision.” The draft says the department must greatly expand its use of artificial intelligence. The proposed reorganization would get rid of regional bureaus. One of the most drastic proposed changes is to eliminate the bureau of African affairs. The draft also said all “nonessential” embassies and consulates in sub-Saharan Africa would be closed by Oct. 1. The department would eliminate a bureau overseeing democracy and human rights issues; one that handles refugees and migration; and another that works with international organizations. The department would establish a new senior position, the under secretary for transnational threat elimination. The Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance would absorb the remnants of the U.S. Agency for International Development. The department would offer buyouts to foreign service and civil service officers until Sept. 30. The State Department has about 80,000 employees. The draft order also calls for narrowing Fulbright scholarships. The draft says the department will end its contract with Howard University. Dan Caldwell, Darin Selnick and Colin Carroll served as senior advisers to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Defense Secretary Stephen Feinberg before they were fired. Gov. Katie Hobbs of Arizona vetoed a bill that would have supported the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement efforts. The bill would have required state and local officials to cooperate with federal immigration officials. resumen:
Asia-Pacific credit conditions remain firmly on the downside, given the escalation in China-US relations and uncertain US trade policy, which are hitting growth and confidence in the region, said S&P Global Ratings.

The Trump administration's 90-day pause of "reciprocal" tariffs (announced on April 2) offers some reprieve for Asia-Pacific economies, but the region is not out of the woods.

The April 2 tariffs affected Asia-Pacific the most. This reflects the prevalence of large bilateral trade surpluses with the US across most countries.

The threat and imposition of tariffs by the US continue to loom over global trade and economic growth and could also reignite US consumer inflation.

Confidence is set to deteriorate further amid halts in new business investments and worsening household sentiment.

Equity and debt markets are likely to stay volatile. Taken together, these economic, consumer, and financial market developments are negative for Asia-Pacific and global credit.

The strained US-China relations will affect Asia-Pacific economies, given the region's integrated trade ties with both countries.

A sharper deterioration in China-US relations will further strain confidence, and severely disrupt supply chains and global trade flows.

These events could spur a sharper global slowdown. These rapid developments have prompted us to raise our assessment of the global trade risk to very high.

For the rest of Asia-Pacific, the partial tariff reprieve broadly cushions current growth assumptions.

Small and trade-centric economies (such as Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, and Taiwan) may face greater obstacles to growth.

Locally produced goods in Asia-Pacific and outside the US could face more intense price competition as Chinese exporters scout new markets and cut prices to accelerate sales.

A redirection of products into regional markets would further squeeze domestic markets or sectors with excess capacity and this could stoke further escalation of protectionist measures within Asia-Pacific.

content: Sen: The question when it comes to longer-term rates (like 10- or 30-year yields) is whether investors would see rate cuts as because of judicious monetary policy or pressure from the president. If it ...
resumen:
Josh Barro hosted a written online conversation with Lael Brainard, the director of the National Economic Council from 2023 to 2025 and a former vice chair of the Federal Reserve, and Conor Sen, a columnist for Bloomberg Opinion, to discuss the risks to and uncertainty in Donald Trump’s economy.

The S&P 500 is down about 14 percent from its peak in February.

Markets were hoping for tax cuts and deregulation, but what was received were spending cuts and fiscal uncertainty created by the Department of Government Efficiency, and then a level of tariffs much higher than anyone expected.

The 10 percent base-line tariff for all countries, the 25 percent sectoral tariffs for cars and other products, the enormous tariffs against China mean huge increases in prices for American working families — for clothing, shoes, cars, housing. These are levels similar to the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, and they are going to hurt families and businesses, costing them $3,000 or more a year, scramble business supply chains and hit the economy.

U.S. Treasury bond yields have risen, and the dollar has weakened compared with other major currencies.

The tariff announcements coming from the White House are raising questions about whether it is a smart bet for global investors to have so much of their money in U.S. assets.

If the strategy is to make the U.S. into more of an exporting country, it is not a smart strategy. Hitting working families with huge price hikes, raising the risk of throwing the economy into a recession, increasing interest costs on the U.S. debt at a time when the administration is planning to issue trillions of dollars of additional debt for tax cuts seems like a self-inflicted mistake.

Putting tariffs on not just final but intermediate goods as well raises the cost of production for U.S. manufacturers.

It would take an enormous permanent shift in the global landscape to fundamentally alter the dollar’s reserve currency status.

Interest rates have been volatile.

The president has reiterated his call for the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates.

The high tariffs imposed by the White House will raise prices for businesses and consumers and contribute to a slowdown in the economy — and that could put Fed policy in a tight spot.

The Fed has two key objectives: keep inflation low and support strong employment.

The administration may say the Fed should cut rates.

Most people think it would be a real mistake for the administration to terminate the Federal Reserve chair before the end of the statutory term (in May 2026).

Businesses cannot predict the tax regime they will operate under, they cannot predict the cost or availability of financing, so they can’t make sound decisions about how to expand or hire.

A recession will be entirely self-inflicted, given that the United States started the year from a position of enviable strength with inflation that has been coming down, strong growth and very good employment.

The easiest dynamic to think about at the moment is this is a shock to the goods economy and supply chains, somewhat similar to what was seen during and after the Covid-19 pandemic.

It is important for Congress to restore the guardrails.

Strategically targeted tariffs are an important part of a strategy that makes sure America can compete fairly in key industries. But it is also important to provide investment incentives.

It doesn’t make any sense to impose high tariffs on countries and products across the board — it just puts an enormous price hike on American working families that can afford it the least, disadvantages U.S. businesses that rely on some imported inputs and risks a recession for no benefit to the United States.

Americans are unhappy about high prices. Tariffs are going to raise prices and lead to less product availability for U.S. consumers.

The surge in consumer inflation expectations is notable.

The debt ceiling standoff and sequester in 2011 between President Barack Obama and Republicans in Congress that cut spending across the board at a time when unemployment was high, inflation was low and the economy was still struggling to recover from the 2008 Great Recession was particularly moronic.

The likelihood of the United States going into recession has increased materially.

The economy started out the year very strong, so it would be malpractice to see a self-inflicted recession.

Every C.E.O. now needs to budget and plan for a recession, which means less hiring and less investment than they budgeted for a month ago.

The consensus is 50-50 odds of a recession.

title: Trump(dis)order: Harsh tariffs rates based on wrong philosophy and wrong formula - (Published 7 hour(s), 25 minute(s) ago)
content: The harsh tariff rates imposed by US President Donald Trump on all exporters to USA have squarely hit the poor countries that export mainly items like apparels and rubber products. ..
resumen:
US President Donald Trump imposed harsh tariff rates on all exporters to the USA, particularly affecting poor countries exporting items like apparels and rubber products, mainly in Asia (Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Vietnam, and Cambodia). These high reciprocal tariffs were due to these countries running a trade surplus with the USA, though a 90-day pause has been implemented. Apparel buyers initially asked exporters to absorb the tariffs, but due to their unaffordable nature, orders were canceled or postponed. In Sri Lanka, both apparel and rubber product exports to the USA have suffered. Trump's tariff revisions have created market uncertainty. Large exporters to the USA like China, Canada, and the EU have retaliated with their own tariffs, leading to a never-ending tariff war.

The economic analyst Dhananath Fernando quoted American economist Otto T Mallery, who stated that if goods don't cross borders on missions of peace, soldiers will cross them on missions of war. Frédéric Bastiat also spoke of the benefits of free trade, implying that wars arise from barriers to free trade.

The author argues that Sri Lanka's focus on the 44% reciprocal tariff is too narrow, as Trump's policy will cause inflation in the USA, reducing the purchasing power of Americans, which will negatively impact Sri Lanka's exports. Retaliatory tariffs from major economic powers will also shrink their economies, further affecting Sri Lanka's exports.

The author has two issues with Trump's tariff revision plan: his interpretation of trade deficits and the formula used to calculate the amount allegedly "robbed" from US citizens. Trump claims trade surpluses indicate plundering of US citizens. The author argues that the US, as the unofficial central banker since 1971, has benefited from exchanging dollars for real goods. The formula used by Trump's advisors is also deemed irrelevant. The formula's co-author, Brent Neiman, disputes its context and application, stating it's not meant for mass-scale use on countries like Sri Lanka. Neiman confirmed that the actual price adjustment factor should have been 0.95, not 0.25, which would collapse the calculations made by Trump's advisors.

title: Opinion/Guest column: Fiscal signs point to US recession ahead - (Published 17 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: The tight monetary policy of the Federal Reserve and chaotic fiscal measures of Trump are not the right corrective measures and worsen the problems.
resumen:
In November, Hans Despain predicted on the Lee Elci radio show in New London, Connecticut, that the U.S. economy would experience a recession before the next presidential election in 2028.

International trade is sputtering due to trade disagreements globally, including those between the U.S. and China, and within the G7 nations, as well as tensions between the G7 and BRICS.

Total business debt stands at an all-time high of $21.6 trillion; $7.8 trillion is noncorporate debt. In 2021, the Federal Reserve estimated the percentage of U.S. firms unable to service their debt was 10%. New research shows that number may be closer to 15%.

Seventy-five percent of American industries have become more concentrated.

Since 1972 average hourly earnings have only increased 81 cents, taking inflation into account, over a 52-year period.

In 2022, it took on average 62.1 weeks of work per year for the average person to meet their cost-of-living expenses.

In 1985 it cost $17,586 for the necessities to “thrive,” and median annual income was $23,036. In 2022 the cost for necessities to “thrive” was $75,732, while median annual income was $63,388.

Household debt is at a record high of $18 trillion.

Auto loans are at an all-time high of $1.66 trillion. Student loans are at an all-time high of $1.61 trillion. Credit card debt is at an all-time high of $1.21 trillion.

The average credit card annual percentage rate in 2013 was 12.9%. By 2021 it was 16%. Today the average APR is 28.72%!

title: What do Trump's tariffs mean for Florida's real estate industry? | Opinion - (Published 15 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: The National Association of Home Builders estimates that tariffs could add over $9,200 to the price of an average new single-family home.
resumen: Tariffs on construction materials are not new, but the current situation is different due to its scale and unpredictability. Tariffs are being applied broadly, impacting nearly every product used by builders and homeowners that isn’t entirely domestically made. Imported materials play a vital role in residential construction, with roughly 10% of materials used in homebuilding being imported. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) estimates that tariffs could add over $9,200 to the price of an average new single-family home, while Zelman & Associates forecasts this figure could climb as high as $25,000 in some markets. Higher renovation costs will discourage homeowners from investing in improvements. For builders, especially those focused on mid-market or entry-level housing, these material cost hikes can be deal breakers. Another potential impact of tariffs may be felt in mortgage rates. Canadians account for approximately 11% of all foreign homebuyers in the U.S., with Florida consistently ranked as their top destination. Recent trade tensions have left many Canadians feeling unwelcome.

title: Billionaire fund manager sends hard-nosed message on recession in 2025 - (Published 14 hour(s), 22 minute(s) ago)
content: The potential that the U.S. economy could deliver a blow to corporate America's revenue and profit has caught the attention of veteran Wall Street fund manager Ken Fisher, the billionaire founder of ...
resumen:
Stocks were hard hit after President Trump announced broad-based tariffs on April 2nd, the so-called “Liberation Day.” The announcement included tariff rates much higher than expected, causing investors to rethink their outlooks for the U.S. economy and corporate earnings. The stock market hit came amid recent data already showing that the U.S. economy is slowing, increasing the possibility that higher inflation caused by tariffs may push us into recession.

Veteran Wall Street fund manager Ken Fisher, the billionaire founder of Fisher Investments, a money management firm with $295 billion in assets under management, recently updated his recession outlook for this year.

In 2021, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell made the mistake of thinking that sparks of inflation were "transitory," only to be forced to embrace the most restrictive monetary policy since the 1980s in 2022. Now, Powell and other Fed members similarly describe the impact of tariffs on inflation as "transitory." Inflation has slowed below 3%, far below its 8% peak in 2022.

Unemployment has risen to 4.2% from its 3.4% low in April 2023. Most still expect first-quarter GDP to be positive. The Conference Board's Expectations Index is just 65, well below the 80 level that suggests a recession is coming. ISM's Manufacturing and Services PMI readings of 49 and 50.8, respectively, are below and near the 50 level associated with contraction.

Fisher weighed in on the likelihood of a recession this year, offering a discouraging outlook if tariffs aren't rolled back following the 90-day pause in reciprocal tariffs implemented on April 9. "If it does not resolve that President Trump and crew have negotiated some deals and then put all of this nonsense behind us, or 90% of all this nonsense behind us, you'll see a very bad economic effect that will cause a recession, and it will be recession before the end of the year," said Fisher on YouTube. Fisher thinks it's too early to declare a recession, given that the stock market usually falls for three to four months before a recession takes hold and that we're only about two months from the peak. "We never get a recession unless the U.S. stock market and global stock market have peaked from an all-time high and gone down for three or fourth months," said Fisher. "It won't start any sooner than that."

Fisher thinks two things must happen to avoid a recession: stocks must find their footing, and the trade war must end. "What President Trump is doing in tariffs is terribly destructive," said Fisher. "But the tariffs that he would impose, if they're sustained...any and all of that is bad. None of it accomplishes what he thinks it will accomplish. None of it." "He somehow, on this matter, and all the advisers that he hand-picked around him as people that already agreed with him on all this stuff, don't actually know what they're talking about," said Fisher. "I've never seen a circumstance like this ever." Fisher, a long-time Republican and major donor to Senate and House races "for a long time," offered a very blunt opinion on President Donald Trump's tariff plan. "If they keep going down this path...they will turn us into recession," added Fisher. "Tariffs always hurt the country that imposes them more than they hurt the country that they're imposed upon."

title: Navigating the US-China-India triangular labyrinth - (Published Apr 19, 2025)
content: It, too, must engage in the gauzy act of balancing within the triangular dynamics of the US, China, and India—an essential yet knotty task that defines political survival, foreign policy coherence, ...
resumen: The advent of a new political party in Bangladesh demands a diplomatic vision rooted not in traditional alignments but in nimble strategic thinking. As global power dynamics tilt towards a volatile balance between the United States, China, and India, the party's survival and success depend on its ability to chart this complex triangle without compromising sovereignty, economic prospects, or democratic integrity. The nature of a political party's foreign policy, especially how it balances international friendships while securing domestic legitimacy, emerges as a cornerstone of governance. The National Citizen Party (NCP) must engage in balancing within the triangular dynamics of the US, China, and India. Bangladesh's political landscape has been influenced by the gravitational pull of external powers, including India, China, and the US. India, being the first state to recognise Bangladesh's sovereignty in 1971, has maintained deep-rooted influence. China has capitalised on economic diplomacy and military assistance, becoming Bangladesh's top trading partner and largest source of foreign investment. The US exerts its power through developmental aid, political influence campaigns, and geopolitical manoeuvring. The challenge for the new political party is to balance three giants while managing their competing pressures within Bangladesh's own political narrative. The party must actively shape its own identity, requiring a disciplined diplomatic front that reflects "strategic equidistance." Today's diplomacy requires a technocratic blend of pragmatism, optics, and influence management. Bangladesh's new political leadership must institutionalise the doctrine of "Middle Path Diplomacy," seeking partnerships based on mutual benefit, national interest, and non-alignment. Bangladesh must leverage China's economic clout without falling into debt traps. With India, it must pursue neighbourly diplomacy that respects sovereignty and mitigates asymmetry. The US remains a key partner in trade and security, but its interventions in domestic politics necessitate a cautious engagement model. Strategic hedging, multilateralism, and soft power projection should be the tripod of this new diplomatic architecture. India poses the most complex diplomatic challenge. India's support of Sheikh Hasina's Awami League and its scepticism of the BNP have long impacted Bangladesh's internal political equilibrium. The new party's India strategy must extend beyond state-to-state diplomacy, engaging India's civil society, intelligentsia, and regional actors. Regional organisations such as SAARC, BIMSTEC, and ASEAN must be rejuvenated as platforms for non-hegemonic cooperation. The African Union's (AU) model is worth studying. Bangladesh's new political party must take inspiration from such models to propose a "Bay of Bengal Compact" or a "South Asian Strategic Community" that ensures collective self-reliance. The US has deployed soft power via USAID and programmes like IRI's "Promoting Accountability, Inclusivity, and Resiliency" initiative. India has utilised both carrot and stick. China quietly embeds itself through infrastructure megaprojects, military sales (accounting for over 70 percent of Bangladesh's arms imports), and strategic port development. The new political party must publicly acknowledge these realities. A future-oriented foreign policy, based on equal dignity, regional solidarity, and multilateral engagement, will help Bangladesh insulate itself from undue influence while maximising economic and security dividends. Alauddin Mohammad is joint member secretary of National Citizen Party (NCP) and executive director at Institute of Policy, Governance and Development (IPGAD).

title: Will trade war lead to import surge in India? | Explained - (Published Apr 19, 2025)
content: Reports say the Ministry of Commerce and Industry is wary of any potential surge in imports of farm produce from the U.S. and manufactured goods from China, Vietnam and Indonesia, among other ...
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs and China’s retaliatory tariffs have induced fears in India about impacted countries re-routing their exports to the large consumer market. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry is wary of any potential surge in imports of farm produce from the U.S. and manufactured goods from China, Vietnam and Indonesia, among other countries.

With President Trump’s tariff regime making it difficult for countries to sell in the U.S., they may potentially look to India’s large consumer market to dispose of their goods, especially goods being extensively produced in their factories beyond their domestic consumption or are of considerable importance to their overall economic and/or export ambitions.

Bangladesh’s readymade garments and textile industry and Indonesia’s electronic equipment industry are two noteworthy examples where this dynamic may play out. The former is the world’s second largest garment manufacturer, with the sector accounting for 80% of its exports. Indonesia’s electronics industry has been a key driver of their economic growth and employment, according to the International Labour Organisation (ILO).

China could be looking for avenues to deal with its manufacturing overcapacity. Manufactured goods accounted for over 95% of China’s exports. In March, data from Chinese Customs pointed to the U.S. as its biggest export destination.

China was the third largest export destination for U.S. agricultural products. Exports declined 15% on a year-over-year basis in 2024 to $24.7 billion because of “rising competition” to U.S. soyabean and corn from South America.

Sectors at most risk include chemicals, steel, aluminium, textiles, plastics, rubber, electronics and consumer goods. Several of these are already under investigation with the Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR).

Preliminary findings of the anti-dumping investigation attributed “trade diversion due to protective measures” imposed by the U.S. and EU (starting 2018) as the “major cause” for surge in imports of certain steel products. The DGTR recommended imposing a provisional safeguard duty of 12% for 200 days in March. In the chemical sector, the DGTR concluded earlier this year that China was dumping titanium oxide into the country and “injuring the domestic sector”.

Consumer products particularly will face “a lot of dumping”. Any potential dumping would particularly bother small industries (such as textiles) which are sparsely distributed and difficult to organise together.

India regularly imposes anti-dumping duties on products from China, Korea and EU, among others, and facing similar actions abroad.

Dumping cannot be countered by competitive pricing because the margins tend to be “huge”. Only trade remedial measures such as safeguards, countervailing measures and/or anti-dumping duties would be of help.

The APEC has already taken up concerns about potential dumping in the sector with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

An anti-dumping duty proposes to rectify the distortive effect of unfair trade practices that entail goods being exported to another country at prices lower than their normal value with a predatory intent, in other words, dumping. Safeguard duties strive to mitigate the impact of a sudden surge in imports.

title: Experta tica describe “incertidumbre” sobre economía local este año - (Published Apr 19, 2025)
content: San José, 19 abr (Prensa Latina) Costa Rica enfrenta un entorno cargado de incertidumbre tras dos años de desaceleración económica a nivel global, ahora signada por los aranceles estadounidenses, advi ...
resumen:
Costa Rica enfrenta un entorno cargado de incertidumbre tras dos años de desaceleración económica a nivel global, ahora signada por los aranceles estadounidenses, advirtió hoy la analista económica del banco de Escocia, Grettel Vásquez.

El panorama de la nación centroamericana se perfila con cautela para el resto de 2025, marcado por una combinación de desafíos internacionales y señales mixtas en el ámbito local.

Un factor principal que condiciona dichas expectativas es el resurgimiento de tensiones comerciales, impulsadas por la reciente aplicación de la política arancelaria del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump contra este y otros países.

Washington impone desde marzo gravámenes de hasta un 25 por ciento a importaciones clave que afectan a países como México, Canadá, China y, en menor medida, a Costa Rica, que enfrenta la conocida tarifa del 10 por ciento.

Estas medidas elevaron la presión inflacionaria global y ya se sienten en los mercados internacionales, contexto en el cual organismos como la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económicos revisan a la baja sus proyecciones de crecimiento.

El Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR) previó para este año un crecimiento del 4,1 por ciento y para 2026 de 4,0 por ciento, tras registrar un 4,3 por ciento en 2024 y un 5,1 por ciento en 2023.

Cifras estas que podrían ser revisadas a la baja si persisten los efectos negativos de los aranceles del 10 por ciento de Estados Unidos sobre los precios y la actividad productiva.

La inflación en el país muestra una trayectoria ascendente, pues la tasa interanual en febrero de 2025 fue de 1,2 por ciento, tras cerrar 2024 con una variación del 0,8 por ciento.

Aunque aún dentro de niveles manejables, el país ya suma tres años fuera del rango meta del BCCR (de entre 2,0 por ciento a 4,0 por ciento), en tanto los grupos de alimentos y vivienda destacan como los principales impulsores del alza, debido a su peso en la canasta de consumo.

El país centroamericano enfrentará un segundo semestre de 2025 con expectativas moderadas, porque, si bien la economía local mantiene una proyección de crecimiento relativamente sólida, el entorno internacional y las referidas tensiones comerciales representan riesgos significativos.

La evolución de los aranceles, el comportamiento de los precios y la reacción del sistema financiero serán claves para definir el cierre del año.

1.  **Cuestionamientos:** Maduro fue proclamado ganador por el Consejo Nacional Electoral (CNE), que controlan rectores afines al chavismo. El Centro Carter concluyó en febrero que las elecciones "no pueden considerarse democráticas". La Plataforma Unitaria Democrática (PUD) denunció la consumación de un "golpe de Estado", al insistir en que el vencedor fue Edmundo González Urrutia.
2.  **Apoyo y rechazo internacional:** Maduro es respaldado por países como Rusia, China, Irán, Turquía, Catar, Bielorrusia, Serbia, Guinea Ecuatorial, Cuba, Nicaragua, Bolivia, Honduras y San Vicente y las Granadinas. Estados Unidos, Canadá, Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Panamá, Paraguay, Perú, Colombia, Brasil, República Dominicana, Uruguay, Reino Unido, Ucrania, Alemania, Italia y Japón, entre otros, han cuestionado su legitimidad.
3.  **Trump vs. Maduro:** Washington endureció las sanciones contra Caracas tras el retorno de Donald Trump a la Casa Blanca, con el fin de las licencias petroleras y la decisión de imponer aranceles del 25 % a los compradores de crudo venezolano, así como tarifas del 15 % a productos de la nación caribeña. Maduro decretó un estado de emergencia económica y Caracas emitió una "alerta de viaje" sobre "riesgos" en EE.UU.
4.  **Migración:** Desde febrero, 2.559 venezolanos han retornado a su país -la mayoría desde EE.UU.-, en 13 vuelos, tres de ellos en aviones del país norteamericano. Maduro denunció una "agresión civilizatoria" contra migrantes en EE.UU., que en marzo deportó a más de 200 personas a El Salvador, acusadas de supuestamente pertenecer a la banda criminal de origen venezolano Tren de Aragua.
5.  **Próximas elecciones:** Este año habrá, al menos, una decena de comicios, entre ellos, los regionales y parlamentarios, que se celebrarán el 25 de mayo. El chavismo también prevé someter a consulta un proyecto de reforma constitucional que elabora una comisión encabezada por el fiscal general, Tarek William Saab, y que deberá ser presentado en mayo.
6.  **Esequibo:** La tensión con Guyana se ha exacerbado con los planes de Caracas de elegir "por primera vez al gobernador" de la Guayana Esequiba. Georgetown pidió a la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ) emitir medidas para exigir a Venezuela "no celebrar elecciones en ninguna parte del territorio guyanés". La Administración de Maduro ha denunciado acciones de Guyana "en alianza con (la petrolera estadounidense) ExxonMobil" en la zona marítima "pendiente por delimitar".
7.  **Economía:** Desde el 10 de enero, la moneda local se ha devaluado un 33 % frente al dólar en el mercado oficial. El Observatorio Venezolano de Finanzas (OVF) registró una inflación acumulada del 36,1 % en el primer trimestre. Sindicalistas y trabajadores exigen un aumento del salario mínimo, que equivale a 1,60 dólares mensuales.
8.  **Derechos humanos:** Familiares de detenidos considerados presos políticos han llevado a cabo numerosas protestas. La ONG Foro Penal computaba hasta esta semana 890 personas arrestadas por motivos políticos -cinco de ellas adolescentes-, 807 menos respecto al balance publicado el pasado 10 de enero.

title: Primeras ondas expansivas de los aranceles de Trump golpearán la economía mundial - (Published Apr 19, 2025)
content: A pocas cuadras de la Casa Blanca, el FMI se dispone a rebajar sus perspectivas de crecimiento económico en nuevas proyecciones publicadas el martes ...
resumen:
Tres semanas después de que el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump declarara una guerra comercial con todo el mundo, nuevos pronósticos y encuestas económicas apuntarán a las consecuencias iniciales.

El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) se dispone a rebajar sus perspectivas de crecimiento económico en nuevas proyecciones publicadas el martes.

Los índices de gerentes de compras de Japón, Europa y Estados Unidos ofrecerán la primera visión coordinada de la actividad manufacturera y de servicios desde que se implementaron los aranceles globales de Trump el 2 de abril.

Las encuestas empresariales de las principales economías también están en el calendario.

La directora gerente del FMI, Kristalina Georgieva, declaró que las nuevas proyecciones de crecimiento incluirán reducciones significativas, pero no una recesión, y también se verán aumentos en las previsiones de inflación para algunos países.

El presidente de la Reserva Federal, Jerome Powell, declaró que el banco central estadounidense está "bien posicionado para esperar una mayor claridad" antes de considerar cambios en la política monetaria, mientras que la presidenta del Banco Central Europeo, Christine Lagarde, no pudo confirmar si la incertidumbre ha alcanzado su punto máximo.

En EE. UU., los inversores estarán atentos a cualquier deterioro adicional en la confianza del consumidor y las expectativas de inflación cuando la Universidad de Michigan publique los datos revisados ​​de abril el viernes.

La campaña electoral canadiense entra en su última semana, con las encuestas sugiriendo que los liberales del primer ministro Mark Carney tienen alrededor de cinco puntos de ventaja, lo que los coloca al alcance de un gobierno mayoritario en medio de una volátil guerra comercial con Estados Unidos.

El negociador comercial Steve Verheul participará en una conferencia en Toronto.

Los datos minoristas de febrero y una estimación preliminar de marzo revelarán si los consumidores canadienses redujeron su gasto por tercer mes consecutivo en medio de la incertidumbre comercial.

En Asia, la semana comienza con el anuncio de las tasas preferenciales de préstamos de China el lunes; los economistas prevén un resultado estable.

Indonesia publicará datos comerciales de marzo el lunes.

Filipinas registrará otro superávit de balanza de pagos para marzo.

Nueva Zelanda publicará las cifras comerciales de marzo el martes, mientras que Taiwán y Hong Kong informarán los datos de empleo.

El banco central de Indonesia mantendrá las tasas por tercera reunión consecutiva.

El martes, los datos preliminares del PMI de abril para Australia, Japón e India brindarán una visión temprana del impacto que la guerra comercial liderada por Estados Unidos tendrá en los sectores manufacturero y de servicios.

Malasia y Singapur publicarán sus lecturas de inflación el miércoles, y también se publicarán los datos de confianza del consumidor de Corea del Sur, un día antes de que el país publique estimaciones anticipadas del producto interno bruto del primer trimestre.

Japón revelará el IPC de Tokio, así como las ventas de los grandes almacenes, mientras que Singapur conocerá los precios de las viviendas particulares del primer trimestre y la producción industrial de marzo el viernes.

En la eurozona, la atención se centrará principalmente en los informes de encuestas. La confianza del consumidor en la región se publica el martes, y el BCE publica su encuesta a analistas profesionales el mismo día. Su informe de seguimiento salarial, que se publicará el miércoles, apunta a una desaceleración del crecimiento salarial.

Los inversores probablemente también prestarán más atención a los PMI que se publicarán en esa fecha, ya que ofrecen una primera visión de la actividad en el sector manufacturero y de servicios desde que se intensificó la avalancha de aranceles estadounidenses a principios de abril.

El jueves se publica la encuesta Ifo sobre la confianza empresarial alemana.

El viernes se publicarán índices similares en Francia.

Los informes del PMI del Reino Unido también se publicarán el miércoles, al igual que las últimas cifras de finanzas públicas de marzo. Los datos de ventas minoristas se publican el viernes.

El Banco Nacional Suizo publicará el jueves sus resultados del primer trimestre y al día siguiente su presidente, Martin Schlegel, se dirigirá a la junta general anual.

El banco central ruso anunciará su última decisión monetaria el viernes.

Argentina publicará el martes sus datos proxy del PIB de febrero.

Colombia publicará los datos de actividad económica de febrero.

El Banco Central de Paraguay podría verse obligado a ajustar su política monetaria desde el nivel actual del 6%, con una inflación que aumenta 100 puntos básicos en cuatro meses, al 4,4%.

Brasil publicará el viernes los datos de inflación de mitad de mes de abril.

México ofrece informes de actividad económica de febrero y de precios al consumidor de mitad de mes.

El Banco de México (Banxico) se reunirá a mediados de mayo para considerar su tasa de referencia, actualmente en el 9%.

content: Your Christmas decorations probably come from this one Chinese city. But anxiety is high, with vendors on the front lines of the US-China trade war.
resumen: In Yiwu, China, nicknamed “Christmas Town,” which supplies nearly 90% of all decorative Christmas goods used in the United States, vendors are grappling with triple-digit tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. America’s overall tariffs on China now exceed 145%, the highest trade penalties imposed by the US in nearly a century. For many vendors, the measures have already cost them customers, slashed their profits and forced them to pivot to other markets. Ran Hongyan, 43, who has been selling Christmas decorations for 15 years, said that after the tariffs hit, she tried offering her American customers a discount to save the relationship, but it didn’t work. Eight out of ten canceled their contracts this year, representing a loss of more than $135,000. The second-biggest exporter of Christmas decorations to the US is Cambodia, where factory wages are even lower than China, but Trump also imposed 49% tariffs on the small Southeast Asian nation, before the recent 90-day pause. Last year, Yiwu sent $81 billion of goods overseas, of which about $11.5 billion went to the US, according to local customs data. Li Xinyao has been working at her family’s imitation flower business at Yiwu market since it was established in 1993. Nie Ziqin, who sells Halloween decorations, said that half of her customers for Halloween decorations were American before the tariffs hit. Last week Beijing raised tariffs on US goods to 125%.

title: Extreme uncertainty sends tremors through central banks and multilateral organizations - (Published 21 hour(s), 28 minute(s) ago)
content: The IMF revises global economic forecasts downwards due to Trump’s trade war while the ECB cuts interest rates for the sixth time ...
resumen:
The ramping up of global trade tensions has become a central issue for central banks and multilateral organizations. Institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank, the World Trade Organization (WTO) and central banks have begun to revise their growth projections and redesign policies. The international economic playbook now has less predictable rules. The WTO is warning of an increasingly fragmented environment that threatens to blur the frameworks of global cooperation and to undermine the exchange of goods and economic growth.

The IMF announced on April 17 that there would be a wave of “significant downgrades” in the growth projections of many countries. The fund rules out a recession, but does insist there will be hikes in inflation forecasts.

IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that prolonged uncertainty raises the risk of tensions in financial markets. World Bank president Ajay Banga warned that greater uncertainty and economic instability will weigh down the world economy.

After declaring a universal general tariff of 10% and additional rates for countries with which the U.S. has a larger trade deficit, Trump announced a 90-day pause to negotiate with nearly 70 governments. The only one not spared from the armistice is China.

Spain’s Economy Minister Carlos Cuerpo met with U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. There was also a meeting between Japan and the U.S., in which no agreement was reached. April 17 saw Trump hobnob with Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.

The European Central Bank (ECB) cut rates for the sixth consecutive time, to 2.25%, in an attempt to counteract the negative economic impact of the tariffs. ECB President Christine Lagarde has acknowledged that the overall picture is being shaped by “exceptional uncertainty” and that the increase in tariff disputes threatens to further dampen exports.

All markets fell after the rate cut. The Ibex 35 closed 0.19% down, the German Dax fell by 0.53%, while the French stock market and the Euro Stoxx 50 fell by more than 0.6%. The Italian Mib, for its part, limited losses to 0.24%.

The Federal Reserve is being more cautious with rate cuts. Its chairman, Jerome Powell, has insisted on the inflationary risks of the tariffs imposed by the White House.

The WTO has cut its growth forecast for trade in goods by almost three points, from an initial increase of 2.7% to a fall of 0.2% by 2025. If the tariff offensive intensifies, the decline would be 1.5% this year and the global economy could fall by 7% in the long term.

title: Comment: What do Trump’s tariffs mean for travel retail wines and spirits? - (Published 23 hour(s), 52 minute(s) ago)
content: As Trump’s trade war escalates, the global drinks industry is bracing for impact. While duty-free may see short-term gains, the wider alcohol market faces a far more sobering reality ...
resumen: As Trump’s trade war escalates, the global drinks industry is bracing for impact. While duty-free may see short-term gains, the wider alcohol market faces a far more sobering reality. US President Donald Trump imposed sweeping tariffs on around 60 countries worldwide on April 2. For the international alcoholic beverage business, the US tariffs are nothing short of disastrous as America remains the world’s most important premium spirits and wine market. The US imposition of a 10% tariff on all UK imports. Mexico is having to cope with a far higher 25% tariff, as are Canada. As for wines and spirits producers in the European Union, they will have to contend with a 20% tariff. The French trade body the Fédération des Exportateurs de Vins & Spiriteaux de France said the tariffs would only create “losers” both in Europe and the United States. US spirits producers, most notably US bourbon makers, are already feeling the heat of the growing trade war. Bourbon is one of several US product categories the EU has identified for a €26bn retaliatory tariff package, and Canada’s boycott of US goods and tit-for-tat 25% tariff is already hurting US distillers. The Distilled Spirits Council of the US (DISCUS) President Chris Swonger called on President Trump to “liberate” US spirits from the tariff disputes, highlighting the fact that 98% of spirits imported into the US originate from countries that have eliminated tariffs on US spirits exports. During the time that we had zero-for-zero tariffs with 51 countries, our industry flourished, benefitting US distillers, farmers and the wider hospitality industry. The duty-free and travel retail channel will be exempt from the tariffs. As importers pass on much of the tariff increases to domestic consumers, price differentials with travel retail will likely widen, making airport prices more attractive to travellers. Tariffs might not be the boon for the travel retail business they first appear, however. The benefit to the duty-free sector of a tariff-driven trade war will also vary significantly from market to market. At US airports, for instance, spirits sales have traditionally been driven by Latin American, Asian and European travellers rather than Americans, lessening the impact of large price differentials between US duty-free and domestic markets. Besides, duty-free and travel retail account for only a small fraction of most alcohol brands’ total sales. The real threat lies in the much larger portion of their business now at risk under Trump’s tariffs.

resumen:
America’s long-languishing factory jobs are a focal point of the Trump administration’s global tariff battles.

Last year, manufacturing employed 1.25 million statewide in California.

California also represents 10% of the nation’s 12.8 million manufacturing workforce.

Texas was No. 2 with 973,600 jobs, followed by Ohio with 683,800, Michigan with 605,600, and Illinois with 578,200.

Since 1995, the nation lost 4.5 million factory workers.

California dropped 468,200 factory workers over these three decades.

New York is down 394,400 jobs, North Carolina is off 363,300, and Ohio lost 353,800.

Eight states gained manufacturing work in this same period, topped by Utah’s 35,800 growth, Nevada, up 31,300, and Idaho adding 12,200.

The nation has lost 26% of its manufacturing jobs since 1995.

California’s down 27%.

Rhode Island lost half its manufacturing work, while New York is down 49%, and Massachusetts and North Carolina lost 44%.

Nevada had the biggest percentage gain, up 88% since 1995.

Then came North Dakota, up 43%, and Utah, up 31%.

California had 7% of its workers at factories last year, the 32nd highest share among the states.

Manufacturing was 8% of the 2024 U.S. job market.

Indiana had 16% of its jobs in manufacturing last year.

Wisconsin had 15%, Iowa had 14%, and Michigan and Alabama were at 13%.

California manufacturing is down from 14% of the job market three decades ago.

North Carolina factories employed 9% of all of the state’s workers last year – down from 24% in 1995.

Arkansas is down to 12% from 23% in 1995.

Mississippi is also at 12%, down from 22% three decades ago.

California factory work ranks No. 5 nationally with an average $30.51 hourly wage, 12% above the national average of $27.11.

The top four are Wyoming ($33.77), Colorado ($32.52), Washington state ($32.35), and Connecticut ($31.38).

Factory wages statewide are only 77% of the typical California worker’s $39.53 hourly rate in all industries.

Factories pay 79% of the average U.S. wage.

Manufacturing pays above or near the statewide norms in five states: Wyoming at 108%, Louisiana at 103%, Texas at 92%, Florida at 92%, and Kentucky at 90%.

Michael Faulkender, Mr. Bessent’s deputy, will be the new acting leader, replacing Gary Shapley. Mr. Faulkender will be the third acting leader of the agency this week.

Mr. Bessent had complained to Mr. Trump that Mr. Musk had done an end run around him to get Mr. Shapley installed as the interim head of the I.R.S.

The position of I.R.S. commissioner will be filled in an acting capacity while former Representative Billy Long awaits Senate approval for the role.

Mr. Bessent praised Mr. Shapley for his “passion and thoughtfulness” and said that he remains an important adviser. Mr. Shapley and another I.R.S. critic of the Hunter Biden tax investigation, Joseph Ziegler, will be assigned to senior roles at the Treasury Department or the I.R.S.

Mr. Trump had picked Mr. Shapley to run the I.R.S. on Tuesday after the previous interim head, Melanie Krause, chose to resign. Ms. Krause quit after the Treasury Department agreed to use I.R.S. data to help Immigration and Customs Enforcement deport undocumented immigrants.

Mr. Musk has said he wants to donate another $100 million through political entities controlled by the president’s team.

As a special government employee, Mr. Musk is allotted 130 days of time on the job.

One of the DOGE members at the I.R.S., Gavin Kliger, was recently pushed out of the agency.

title: U.S. tariffs could cost Germany 290 bln euros: report - (Published 13 hour(s), 54 minute(s) ago)
content: BERLIN, April 18 (Xinhua) -- U.S. tariffs could slash Germany's economic output by as much as 290 billion euros (330 billion U.S. dollars) over four years, the German Economic Institute (IW) has ...
resumen: U.S. tariffs could slash Germany's economic output by as much as 290 billion euros (330 billion U.S. dollars) over four years, the German Economic Institute (IW) has warned, projecting an annual GDP loss of 1.6 percent for Europe's largest economy by 2028. The report analyzes the potential fallout from the "reciprocal tariffs" announced by U.S. President Donald Trump on April 2, which would impose an additional 20 percent duty on imports from the European Union (EU), among other trading partners, citing large trade deficits. According to the IW, Germany's direct losses from these measures could reach 200 billion euros, or 1.2 percent of GDP annually by 2028. With retaliatory responses factored in, total damages may rise to 290 billion euros. The EU as a whole could face cumulative losses of up to 1.1 trillion euros by 2028, the report estimated. Germany, a highly export-oriented economy, has posted a trade surplus with the United States for 33 consecutive years. In 2024, this surplus reached a record 69.8 billion euros. Data from Germany's statistical authorities showed that the United States accounted for 10.4 percent of Germany's total exports last year, the highest share since 2002. The IW urged the EU to respond decisively, suggesting that retaliation could extend beyond goods to include U.S. digital firms and other service sectors. (1 euro = 1.14 U.S. dollar)

title: Consider the Lobster Tariffs: Trump’s Trade War Has Santa Barbara County’s Fishing and Ag Industries on Edge - (Published 9 hour(s), 0 minute(s) ago)
content: The vast majority of the lobster sold out of Central California grows in the cold waters of the Santa Barbara Channel and is exported live to Chinese markets. Lobster fishers are already worried about ...
resumen:
About 330,000 pounds of lobster lands at Santa Barbara's harbor each year. The vast majority of the lobster sold out of Central California grows in the cold waters of the Santa Barbara Channel and is exported live to Chinese markets. Lobster fishers are already worried about what the Trump tariffs will do to the market, once the season opens in October, said Chris Voss, president of the Santa Barbara Commercial Fishermen.

California State Treasurer Fiona Ma spoke on the tariffs’ impacts on consumers during a recent press call organized by Americans for Responsible Growth. About 330,000 pounds of lobster lands at Santa Barbara’s harbor, brought in by 45 fishers at an economic benefit of about $7 million last year, according to California Fish & Wildlife. Statewide, lobster represents a $24.2 million business. This time around felt like a repeat of the tariffs imposed during Trump’s first term, Voss said. Some workarounds were given for the economic loss back then, “but the scale of it now is so dramatic,” said Voss.

In a press call on Wednesday, Colorado’s Dave Young stressed that Trump’s chaotic and “reckless trade agenda has fueled uncertainty and fear across the globe, creating a self-inflicted crisis” that affected farmers’ and ranchers’ ability to buy machine parts and fertilizer. The treasurers of Minnesota and Illinois recalled the effect on soybeans during the previous Trump Administration’s tariffs, effectively switching China’s purchases to Brazil, a market loss from which domestic family farms were still recovering.

California’s state treasurer, Fiona Ma, emphasized the tariffs’ effects on consumers’ pocketbooks. On the day the tariffs were announced, she recalled, four truckloads of produce at the Mexican border were stuck until they paid the tariff. “This is what happened,” Ma said. “They charged their vendors; the vendors increased prices on the people. That’s how these tariffs work. They increase prices.”

Last week it was a 145 percent tariff, but on Tuesday, the White House had announced China faced up to a 245 percent tariff on imports to the U.S. It later had to explain that the number was a total of the tariffs since the first Trump Administration. China’s retaliatory tariff is a 125 percent tax on U.S. goods.

Wine, the county’s top finished agricultural product, was hit with an added 15 percent tariff in 2018, during Trump’s previous trade war with China. This time around, all U.S. goods, including wine, can expect a 125 percent tax to be applied as an entry duty to China.

In 2018 there was a big drop in exports, and then the COVID pandemic slowed things further, said JiaMin Dierberg, the director of international sales for Dierberg Vineyard, located in the Santa Rita Hills outside Buellton. According to the county Agricultural Commissioner’s office, among the items exported to China in 2023 were 5,275 empty wine barrels for liquor production and about 28 pounds of flower and vegetable seed. Santa Barbara County produces more than a million cases of wine annually, as well as selling nearly $1 billion in grapes for wines made across California.

Among Santa Barbara County’s chief exports are strawberries, and the county’s top export country is Canada. Canadian leaders agreed during a debate on Wednesday that they had stopped buying strawberries from the U.S. on principle.

title: Trump tariffs live updates: US moves to levy Chinese ships as Trump softens rhetoric - (Published 12 hour(s), 20 minute(s) ago)
content: The US took steps to impose levies on Chinese ships that dock at US ports, escalating the trade war between the world's two largest economies. On Thursday, President Trump struck an optimistic tone ...
resumen:
President Trump signaled he was open to negotiations with trading partners this week, even as the US took steps to escalate its trade war with China. On Thursday, Trump struck an optimistic tone about negotiations with China, stating "we are going to make a very good deal with China." He also touted talks with the country, adding that he is reluctant to keep raising tariffs on China and may even want them to be lower to protect consumer spending. Trump also claimed positive developments in talks with other countries. He said Japan talks saw "big progress," though Japan's Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato expressed concerns over the global economic fallout. He described a call with Mexico's president Claudia Sheinbaum "very productive" and hosted Italy Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni at the White House. China has shown openness to trade talks with the US, contingent on specific conditions, despite the White House clarifying that "China now faces tariffs of up to 245% on imports to the United States." China raised its duties on imports of US goods to 125% from 84%, while US tariffs on Chinese imports have ballooned — to "a 125% reciprocal tariff, a 20% tariff to address the fentanyl crisis, and Section 301 tariffs on specific goods, between 7.5% and 100%." US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said he was optimistic about "clarity" on tariffs and progress on key trade deals. Trump has signaled a possible delay to auto levies after suspending duties on some consumer tech, even as he insists these tariffs will eventually come to fruition. The baseline 10% tariff that went into effect on April 5 remains in place for all affected imports into the US.

Netflix co-CEO Gregory Peters stated, "We've certainly seen periods of challenging economic conditions historically in different countries. And we've generally been able to keep that positive flywheel spinning even in those situations. And I think that speaks to ... that we are, for many people, a very good value, even as they're being careful about where they spend." L'Oréal CEO Nicolas Hieronimus stated, "Most of our [consumer] brands, CeraVe, are manufactured in North America. So what is exported is mostly luxury. ... We can take prices up. We have built inventory. And yes, we can relocate some of our productions. But of course, we don't want to ... take any measures on something that might be temporary. So we are watching carefully what's happening and trying to figure out what will be the end game." American Express CEO Stephen Squeri stated, "I think small businesses are the ones that we would pay a lot more attention to just because ... they could be put in a situation and will not be able to compete effectively in the market." Squeri also said that so far, spending has been "as strong as it was last quarter, maybe slightly, slightly stronger, and credit still continues to look really good."

Ryan Petersen, CEO of Flexport, wrote that a wave of American small businesses "will go bankrupt this year if the tariff policies on China don’t change." Peterson asserted that "around $1T" in economic activity has already been lost.

Vietnam’s Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh said his nation has a “unique bond” with the US as his government engages in trade talks with the Trump administration to avoid a large tariff on its products.

Toyota is considering producing the next version of its top-selling RAV4 SUV in the United States.

Japan issued a monthly report that mentioned trade uncertainty amid new US policies. "The economy is recovering moderately, while uncertainty is arising from U.S. trade policies," the Japan Cabinet Office report stated.

President Trump said that China had reached out to the US to negotiate on trade and that he viewed hiking tariffs on the country any further unfavorably.

Trump said, "We're doing very well with negotiations, I think, with all countries," and "We have a lot of countries that want to make a deal. Frankly, they want to make deals more than I do." Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent highlighted recent talks with Japan, the EU, South Korea, and India. "We're working on the big 15 economies," Bessent said.

France's Hermes announced that it will pass the full impact of tariffs onto its affluent US customers, following a first-quarter sales report that slightly fell short of market expectations.

Hong Kong’s postal service will stop handling shipments to and from the US in retaliation for President Trump's decision to eliminate the “de minimis exception,” which allowed goods worth $800 or less to be shipped to the US without tariffs. This move, effective April 27, impacts both sea and air shipments. The US introduced new tariffs of up to 120% on goods previously covered by the exemption. Hong Kong’s government condemned the US actions as “unreasonable” and warned of rising costs for consumers. Hong Kong now faces the same 145% tariff on exports as mainland China, after the US revoked Hong Kong’s special trade status in 2020. Hong Kong's leader John Lee condemned the US move and announced plans to file a complaint with the World Trade Organization.

Japan's exports climbed for a sixth consecutive month in March.

title: Ford pauses shipments SUVs, sports cars and other models to China - (Published 12 hour(s), 1 minute(s) ago)
content: Ford has halted exports of key US-built vehicles to China amid rising tariffs and trade tensions, impacting a once-profitable segment of its business, WSJ reports. Engine shipments continue.
resumen:
Ford ha suspendido las exportaciones de sus SUV, camionetas y autos deportivos a China debido a los aranceles de represalia impuestos en medio de las tensiones comerciales en curso bajo el expresidente Donald Trump, según informó el Wall Street Journal el viernes.

Esta semana, el fabricante de automóviles detuvo los envíos de sus F-150 Raptors, Mustangs, Bronco SUV fabricados en Michigan y Lincoln Navigators fabricados en Kentucky al mercado chino, según informes.

Ford dijo en un comunicado: "Hemos ajustado las exportaciones de EE. UU. a China a la luz de los aranceles actuales".

La pausa en la exportación se atribuye a la escalada de los aranceles, con China apuntando a las importaciones de vehículos estadounidenses en respuesta a las medidas comerciales de EE. UU.

Según el WSJ, el negocio de exportación a China representa una operación pequeña pero rentable para Ford.

La compañía ganó aproximadamente $900 millones en ganancias operativas de sus operaciones en China el año pasado, dijo el vicepresidente de Ford, John Lawler, en una conferencia reciente.

Se espera que las exportaciones de Ford de motores y transmisiones fabricados en EE. UU. a China continúen a pesar de la pausa en las exportaciones de vehículos ensamblados.

También se espera que su modelo Lincoln Nautilus, que se fabrica en China, continúe con los envíos, a pesar de los fuertes aranceles.

En 2024, Ford envió alrededor de 5,500 Broncos, F-150, Mustangs y Navigators a China, una fuerte disminución del promedio anual de más de 20,000 vehículos enviados en la última década.
